newsitem.title: GREECE: PRESS DIGEST - GREEK GENERAL NEWS - DEC 3.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - GREEK GENERAL NEWS - DEC 3.

text.p: Leading stories in the Greek general press:

--The continuing blockade of national roads by farmers and their rejection of all the government's proposals so far has led the situation to a dangerous impasse which threatens the normal functioning of the economy. Last night farmers from Larissa organised a coordinating committee for the entire country while the government is now worried about the economic consequences an expanded protest could have.

--The Cypriot government, with the consent of Athens, appears prepared to accept a US proposal to suspend Greek air force flights over the island. Sources say Athens agrees with this year-long 'temporary decision' on the condition the US initiative on resolving the Cyprus issue proceed with 'due seriousness and effectiveness'.
--An assessment of the damage wrought by the weekend's floods in the Xanthi prefecture began yesterday in the face of forecasts of a new wave of bad weather.

--As the sixth day of the farmers' blockades gets under way the government says it is not yet considering sending in riot police to break up the blockade and that there are no funds to satisfy farmers' demands running into tens of billions of drachmas.

--The farmers' response to the government's proposals is to throw up more road blocks and demands. The agriculture ministry's offer of resettlement of farmers' debts and commitment to cotton farmers was turned down flat.
--Prices for meat were up by 50-100 drachmas at the Athens central market yesterday as the farmers blockade began to bite. Supplies to the market were down by 40 percent.

--Sources say Agriculture Minister Stephanos Tzoumakas feels he has become the lamb to the slaughter over the blockades as farmers demand to speak to the prime minister. The number of road blocks is up to 44 around the country from 27 yesterday.
--Dora Bakoyianni, a central figure in the conflict currently under way in the conservative opposition party New Democracy, says she is not thirsty for power.
--Environment, Town Planning and Public Works Minister Costas Laliotis promises flood-stricken Xanthi results in seven days. --Maria Petrakis, Athens Newsroom +301 3311812-4
